FORTHCOMING OVERSEA VISIT
(Statement by the Chief Minister)


    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, I should like to make a statement on my forthcoming visit.

Column: 1306



    Sir, I have received an invitation from the Government of Ceylon to visit Ceylon, and I shall be their guest on the 2nd and 3rd of December. I have also received an invitation from the Government of India, and with my colleague the Assistant Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy), will be their guests in Bombay on the 5th, and we will be in New Delhi between the 6th and the 9th of December. I am scheduled to be in London with the Minister for Labour and Welfare (Mr Lim Yew Hock) and the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat) between the 9th and the 16th of December. Although the suggestion, Sir, originally came from the Secretary of State that it would be helpful if we were to visit England towards the end of this year, there is no indication as yet that we will be the guests of the United Kingdom during our seven-day stay in London. We will, however, be the guests of the Prime Minister and the Secretary of State at official functions. On our return journey we have been invited by the Pakistan Government to be their guests, and it is probable that all three Ministers will be in Karachi for one or two days.

    I should like to indicate briefly the reasons for these courtesy visits and the London visit. During the many functions that attended the Colombo Plan conference, Sir, here in Singapore, I became conscious of feelings of friendship for Singapore and strong sympathy for its political aspirations from many countries, both inside and outside the Commonwealth. The visits to Ceylon, India and Pakistan are intended to strengthen this friendly feeling and this sympathy. I would add that I expect to learn a great deal from the leaders of these countries who have arduously blazed the trail to independence, a trail which we are now following. All Singapore, I am sure, is proud of the honour India, Pakistan and Ceylon do us in extending these official invitations.

    On the visit to London, I wish to reiterate that, apart from seeking to obtain clarification of the British Government's

Column: 1307

attitude to the Labour Front's citizenship proposals, we shall seek officially only to fix a date for a constitutional conference and to agree on an agenda. For the rest, Sir, during those seven days my colleagues and I will be addressing a large number of gatherings. We will seek to make England conscious of the fact that in this lovely island of ours there are more than 1,200,000 human beings with a human being's primordial urge and moral right to be free from subjugation.

    There is one other matter that I would like to touch on. The Government of Thailand has extended an invitation to us to visit Thailand on our return journey. It is our view that the first visit to a close trading neighbour should be of a fuller character than would be possible in this hurried visit. Many of us are conscious of the impetus of the goodwill mission to Indonesia not only in the realm of commerce but especially in the realm of friendly relations which will be an important factor in our future. I have therefore indicated to the Thai Government, Sir, that we are grateful for the honour they do us, but are unable to accept the invitation at present. We look forward with pleasurable anticipation to the possibility of an invitation for a full mission from Singapore to visit Thailand in the new year.

    Head 61 -

    The Chairman: We are on Head 61. Mr Lee Kuan Yew:

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Chairman, Sir, I move,

    To reduce by $18,240 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 1 (8), Senior Executive Engineers, Grade G, on page 244 of the Estimates.

    Mr Chairman, Sir, in the Remarks column it is indicated "Increase one to include the appointment of Senior Executive Engineer (Defence Services) now abolished." At sub-head 1 (15), this particular appointment which is being abolished is put as "Senior Executive Engineer (Defence Service), Grade G - Abolished."

Column: 1309



    We heard the Minister for Communications and Works yesterday trying to impress us with his Ministry's efficient pruning by the reduction of redundant superscales. We want an explanation of why it is found necessary, when a post is abolished, to create a new one to absorb the person whose post has been abolished.

    Question proposed.

    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): Sir, during the last few days we have listened to the Member for Tanjong Pagar speaking on motions to remove new posts from the Estimates. These motions have covered a wide field - in fact, all the posts which an expatriate might conceivably be appointed to, or required for, or promoted to. The reason generally given for the motion was that the post was unnecessary and that it should be removed. Latterly, however, he came out into the open and suggested that the posts were deliberately created for the benefit of the expatriates now envisaging abolition and that the elected Ministers had, shall we say, been hoodwinked into agreeing to their inclusion. I had intended to answer that suggestion yesterday, Sir, but I thought perhaps I might speak in heat and it would be better that I deferred the matter until today. That suggestion, Sir, is a base and dishonourable suggestion which can only stem from ignoble and dishonest minds. It impugns the intelligence of the elected Ministers and the integrity of the civil service, both expatriate and locally domiciled, which over the past 80 years, by its unswerving devotion to duty, its conscientiousness, its incorruptibility and its sense of justice and fair play, has built up a reputation second to none. The suggestion is so ridiculous that no one will believe it, apart from a handful of unhappy bigots who conceived it and a measure of whose judgment and ability the suggestion is. Even the hon. mover of the motion, being a man of great intellectual ability and integrity, knows in his heart that it is false, absolutely false.

Column: 1310



    Perhaps if I explain the procedure in dealing with applications for new posts, it will put the suggestion in its true perspective. Proposals for new posts must be in the hands of the Treasury by the 15th of April. The great majority are received in February and March. The proposals put up by the heads of departments are considered with great care in the Treasury. Many factors, such as the planned expansion of a department to meet the growing needs of the public, the duties to be performed, the qualifications and experience required, the responsibilities to be borne, staffing requirements generally - all these matters are considered in the Treasury. Other branches of Government are consulted. The head of a department himself is called up to amplify and explain his proposals. In the end all the proposals are considered against the background of the financial position of the Colony, and only those are approved for entry in the Draft Estimates which are absolutely imperative for the successful and efficient conduct of the business of government. In this connection over the years, the Treasury has built up perhaps an unenviable reputation for being difficult in respect of new appointments. I should also like to make it quite clear that in deciding whether an appointment should be entered or not, the only criterion - I repeat, the only criterion - is need, the need of Government, the need of the public. The question whom the post is to be filled by is completely irrelevant.

    Sir, all the posts entered this year have satisfied this criterion and need. They have been proposed by officers of long administrative experience who have only the efficiency and successful operation of their departments in mind, men who, as a result of that experience, can look ahead and see the needs of the future. They have been vetted by a succession of officers of wide administrative and financial experience, whose duty it is - and they have never failed in that duty - to eliminate any proposal which is not justified.

Column: 1311



    What has now happened, Sir, is that the judgment of these acknowledged experts has been challenged and called in question by a small band of civil servants who, to the best of my knowledge, are not qualified to say whether posts in, say, the Medical Department, or the Audit Department, or the Accountant-General's Department, are necessary or not in the public interests or for the efficient discharge of government business. In expressing these opinions, they appear to have been actuated by motives which reasonable men and women would spurn with contempt. What they say in effect is this: that it is better that a post should remain uncreated or unfilled rather than that they should run the risk of having it filled by an expatriate. All I can say is this, Sir, that this bigoted judgment will be small comfort to the parents of a child whose life is perhaps lost because specialised knowledge which might otherwise have been available is lacking. That, I think, Sir, sums up the matter. The honest opinion of disinterested civil servants of long experience is called in question by a small band of bigots of little or no experience. I think judgment in this matter can safely be left to the intelligent members of the public and to the large body of the civil service with whom I have worked for many years and for whom I have the highest respect.

    Lastly, Sir, I should like to touch on the suggestion that elected Ministers were, shall we say, hoodwinked. This is a dishonest, scurrilous and disreputable suggestion.

    The Chairman: Order. The hon. Member is, of course, aware that he must not use unparliamentary words in this Assembly, no matter how much he feels like using those words. "Dishonest", "scurrilous" and "disreputable" are possibly unparliamentary.

    Mr Hart: In the circumstances, Sir, I beg leave to withdraw those expressions.

    This year, since we had some prior warning through the Press that certain new superscale posts might be the subject of attack by a small unhappy group

Column: 1312

of the civil service, it was decided by the Council of Ministers that all proposals would be examined by its Finance Committee. This has been done. The need for each post was examined in great detail. Heads of departments were called up for discussion in most cases. Some posts were deleted. Those which remain are those which satisfied the elected Ministers that they were essential for the efficient discharge of government business.

    The Minister for Communications and Works (Mr Francis Thomas): I think I have only got a minute or two left, Mr Chairman, to deal with this matter. I find it difficult to express my sense of disgust at the profound absurdity of these amendments which the Member for Tanjong Pagar continues to move.

    His objection here is simply to the removal of two brackets and two or three words. The title of the post has been abolished, but the works still remain. What is going to happen in the future will be that the Executive Engineer concerned with defence works will still continue to do it, but if the defence work is slack for a period, he can do other work. If there is a lot of defence work to be done, then another engineer can help him with it; that is the simple effect of this change. I think, in fact, I could have had this shut out under Standing Order 33 (1) (b). If this amendment were accepted, Mr Chairman, there would be no money to pay the officer concerned in this post, and consequently he would have to live rather meagrely on his expatriate allowance and his variable allowance which would not get him very far.

    I wish to make it quite clear that this is a preposterous objection to a mere change in the designation of the work for the purposes of greater administrative flexibility.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: I am glad, Mr Chairman, Sir, that it is an expatriate who finally has to answer for these things. He has alleged that it is an unhappy band of bigots, unbalanced men

Column: 1313

with scurrilous minds and scurrilous hearts, who have made these allegations, and the Chief Minister yesterday was astonished that representations were not, in fact, made to him.

    I made enquiries yesterday to find out the reason for this. As early as the 17th of October this year, the Federation of Government Union Employees, the Singapore Senior Officers Association, the Graduate Teachers Association and the Singapore Teachers Union wrote to the Chairman of the Malayanisation Commission and sent copies of the letter to the Chief Secretary and to the Chief Minister. They were dealing with the creation of superscale posts to which they took the strongest possible exception. I do not know how much time I have, Mr Chairman, Sir, and I wish to read only the relevant passages. The penultimate paragraph of that letter, to which they have had no acknowledgment or reply from the Chief Minister or the Chief Secretary, -

    The Chief Minister: The letter was not addressed to us.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: - says:

    "We do urge the Commission to make an interim recommendation to Government that the Singapore Establishment should be fixed as from the date of the appointment of the Commission, and that no new Division I posts, whether timescale or superscale, should be created by Government without prior reference to the Commission. We also request the Commission to make an interim recommendation to Government that no superscale posts in Division I should be filled substantively on the advice of the present Public Services Commission until after the recommendations of the Malayanisation Commission are known. We are sending copies of the letter to the Chief Secretary and the Chief Minister - "

    The Chairman: Order. I think I have to interrupt the hon. Member because it seems to me that the Malayanisation Commission is a quasi-judicial body and this document was sent to them and perhaps ought not to have been referred to, except possibly in passing.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, this is not a confidential communication to the Malayanisation Commission.

Column: 1314

This was a point of view publicly declared and proclaimed by the Federation of Government Union Employees, the Singapore Senior Officers Association, the Graduate Teachers Association, and the Singapore Teachers Union. They proclaimed it publicly. They sent copies to the Chief Minister and the Chief Secretary. They stated in clear categorical terms that they were against the creation of any new Division I posts. The Chief Minister will have to answer to the people. The Financial Secretary does not have to answer to the people. He does not have to answer to the bigots. If he does not like them, he can call them bigots. But the Chief Minister will have to answer to the people whether he likes them or not, and whether they are bigots or not, because they represent the will of the people.

    The Chairman: Order, order. The time has elapsed.

    Head 62 -

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Chairman, Sir, I beg to move,

    To reduce by $10 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 4 (1), Upkeep of Government Roads, on page 251 of the Estimates.

    In moving this amendment, my attention was drawn to the fact that an allocation of $130,000 has been made under this head as against one of $10,000 in 1955. I would have no objection to this increase if provision is being made for at least one item, or rather group of items. I refer to the approach roads to schools. All three of the main Government schools in the Tanglin Division have approach roads which are in appalling condition, and I know that these are by no means the only schools which are suffering. This matter has already been brought to the notice of the Minister for Education, and I hope that this increase means that the information has been passed on to his colleague at the Ministry of Communications and Works.

Column: 1315



    Sir, the argument which might be used is that roads leading to schools are not the responsibility of the Government because they are frequently private roads to be made up by frontagers, but in the three cases I have quoted the schools are the very first buildings situated on the roads in question, and it seems to me that it is part of the duty of Government, when building and maintaining schools, to build and maintain serviceable approach roads to them. I hope that the Minister will give an assurance that the increase under this head is intended at least in part for this purpose.

    Question proposed.

    Mr Francis Thomas: This vote is in respect of some 120 miles of Government roads which include car parks and access roads, roads to hospitals, prisons, Mount Pleasant Road, Haig Road and so on. I am afraid, Mr Chairman, Sir, I cannot give you a clear picture of what will be done about school approach roads in particular. I am very well aware of the situation, Sir. When I was a teacher, the approach road to my own school was exceedingly bad. I very warmly sympathise with the hon. Member for his efforts to get the roads improved.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Chairman, Sir, it is not clear to me from the remarks of the Minister whether these roads will be attended to or not.

    Mr Francis Thomas: I am afraid he will have to remain unclear for the moment.

    To reduce by $10 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 6 (7), Minor Works, on page 252 of the Estimates.

    In the Estimates it is shown that $150,000 is required this year for minor works. The approved estimate last year was only $60,000. I now seek information as to the necessity for the increase of this vote by 250 per cent and the work to be done.

    Question proposed.

    Mr Francis Thomas: This is a simple little grant of money which is used for im-

proving Crown land when you anticipate building or other work of that kind; for example, the filing up of the swamp land at Kolam Ayer for civil defence purposes; the taking up now of some bits of concrete flooring at Shenton Way which will have to go at some time. That is the general purpose - where Crown land needs to be cleaned up and put into good order, perhaps with a view to building, then the work is put in hand and the work is done.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: That is not very much information, but still I thank him for the little he has given me.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Chairman, Sir, I should like to refer for a few moments to the question of flood alleviation. I am glad that the Bedok scheme has now been started and will be completed, I hope, to the satisfaction of the residents there in a few months.

    But I would ask the Minister now to turn his attention to the Ulu Pandan area. He stated, in reply to the Member for Tanjong Pagar the other day,

Column: 1317

that plans must be formulated before money can be spent. But I would remind him that a plan already exists in the Ulu Pandan area. It was formulated two years ago, published in fact in July 1953 by the Flood Alleviation Joint Committee, composed of representatives of the Government and the City Council, which recommended a scheme to take water away from Alexandra and Bukit Timah through Ulu Pandan to the sea. The Alexandra canal scheme was originally estimated to cost about $4 millions, and this was subsequently reduced to a one million dollar scheme. Finally, however, it was decided first to go forward with a pilot scheme to make sure that the waters of Alexandra would run away in a westerly direction and the reverse direction from what it does at present at a cost of $120,000, of which Government agreed to pay $60,000. Eventually this scheme was completed, I think, about nine months ago at a cost of $200,000, the extra cost being due largely to the need to purchase land from the War Department. I say this scheme was successfully completed in the neighbourhood of nine months ago and I think I stated in this House in April that the water was running away in the right direction, that is to say, in a westerly direction.

    But what has happened since then? A lot of the canal has silted up. Enterprising farmers are now growing water-hyacinth in ponds for their pigs, and the water at the top end of the canal is now running in the opposite direction back towards Alexandra and the city. It seems to me that a scheme which has cost the public $200,000 and was successful should be followed up immediately and that money should have been granted in the 1956 Estimates to see that what has been done already is not wasted but is being carried on.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Mr Chairman, Sir, I have only got at present the preliminary very brief mention about Ulu Pandan. The Member for Tanglin's remarks do seem to me to indicate that if the work done is silting up and if farmers are interfering with it, - do I understand

I cannot anticipate the expert report which we shall get in the course of the next few weeks. I hope early next year it will be available for discussion by the Assembly.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Chairman, Sir, water-hyacinth growing and silting of the canal does indicate a lack of supervision and a lack of interest rather than anything else.
